definition[0]: to destroy something, or to be destroyed, by an explosion
example[0]: The plane blew up in midair.
example[1]: Rebels attempted to blow up the bridge.
definition[1]: to fill something with air or gas
example[2]: Can you blow up this balloon?
definition[2]: if a situation, argument etc blows up, it suddenly becomes important or dangerous
example[4]: A crisis had blown up over the peace talks.
definition[3]: if you blow up a photograph, you make it larger
definition[4]: to become very angry with someone
example[5]: Jenny’s father blew up when she didn’t come home last night.
example[6]: I was surprised at the way he blew up at Hardy.
definition[5]: if bad weather blows up, it suddenly arrives
example[7]: It looks as if there’s a storm blowing up.
definition[6]: if something you have done or planned to do blows up in your face, it suddenly goes wrong
example[8]: One of his deals had just blown up in his face.
definition[7]: a photograph, or part of a photograph, that has been made larger
definition[8]: a sudden big argument or disagreement
